member.name: T:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding
member.summary: Internal Uno behavior, use VisibleBoundsPadding instead.
member.remarks: This class is located in the same source file as the VisibleBoundsPadding class to avoid code duplication. This is required to ensure that both Uno.UI styles and UWP (through Uno.UI.Toolkit) can use this behavior and not have to synchronize two code files. The internal implementation is not supposed to be used outside of the Uno.UI assembly, Uno.UI.Toolkit.VisibleBoundsPadding should be used by dependents.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.WindowPadding
member.summary: The padding of the visible area relative to the entire window.
member.remarks: This will be 0 if the entire window is 'safe' for content.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.OffsetVisibleBounds
member.summary: VisibleBounds offset to the reference frame of the window Bounds.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.SetPaddingMask(Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObject,Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.PaddingMask)
member.summary: Set the to use on this property. A mask of will apply visible bounds padding on all sides, a mask of will adjust only the bottom padding, etc. The different options can be combined as bit flags.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.AreBoundsAspectRatiosConsistent
member.summary: If false, ApplicationView.VisibleBounds and Window.Current.Bounds have different aspect ratios (eg portrait vs landscape) which might arise transiently when the screen orientation changes.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.VisibleBoundsDetails.CalculateVisibilityPadding(Windows.Foundation.Rect,Windows.Foundation.Rect)
member.summary: Calculate the padding required to keep the view entirely within the 'safe' visible bounds of the window.
member.param: The safe visible bounds of the window.
The bounds of the control, in the window's coordinates.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.VisibleBoundsDetails.AdjustScrollablePadding(Windows.UI.Xaml.Thickness,Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ScrollViewer)
member.summary: Apply adjustments when target view is inside of a ScrollViewer.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.VisibleBoundsDetails.CalculateAppliedPadding(Uno.UI.Behaviors.InternalVisibleBoundsPadding.PaddingMask,Windows.UI.Xaml.Thickness)
member.summary: Calculate the padding to apply to the view, based on the selected PaddingMask.
member.param: The padding required to keep the view entirely within the 'safe' visible bounds of the window.
member.returns: The padding that will actually be set on the view.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Controls.BindableView.MoveViewTo(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves a view from one position to another position, without unloading it.
member.param: The old index of the item
The new index of the item
member.remarks: The trick for this method is to move the child from one position to the other without calling RemoveView and AddView. In this context, the only way to do this is to call BringToFront, which is the only available method on ViewGroup that manipulates the index of a view, even if it does not allow for specifying an index.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Controls.TextPaintPool.GetPaint(Windows.UI.Text.FontWeight,Windows.UI.Text.FontStyle,Windows.UI.Xaml.Media.FontFamily,System.Double,System.Double,Windows.UI.Color,Android.Graphics.Shader,Windows.UI.Xaml.Documents.BaseLineAlignment,Windows.UI.Text.TextDecorations)
member.summary: Builds a TextPaint configuration.
member.remarks: This is required for some JNI related reason. At some point, the reference to a member field TextPaint gets collected if used in some of the StaticLayout methods, so we create a local copy of the paint to be used in this context. One solution could be to use a , but the release of the reference can be tricky to place properly.
member.returns: A instance.

members.member: Allows complete control over the colors drawn in the tab layout. Set with {@link #setCustomTabColorizer(TabColorizer)}.
@return return the color of the indicator used when {@code position} is selected.

Set the custom {@link TabColorizer} to be used.
If you only require simple custmisation then you can use {@link #setSelectedIndicatorColors(int...)} to achieve similar effects.

Set the {@link ViewPager.OnPageChangeListener}. When using {@link SlidingTabLayout} you are required to set any {@link ViewPager.OnPageChangeListener} through this method. This is so that the layout can update it's scroll position correctly.
@see ViewPager#setOnPageChangeListener(ViewPager.OnPageChangeListener)
Sets the associated view pager. Note that the assumption here is that the pager content (number of tabs and tab titles) does not change after this call has been made.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.AutomationPeer.UseSimpleAccessibility
member.summary: Enable a mode that simplifies accessibility by automatically grouping accessible elements into top-level accessible elements. The default value is false.
member.remarks:
When enabled, the accessibility name of top-level accessible elements (elements that return a non-null AutomationPeer in and/or have set to a non-empty string) will be an aggregate of the accessibility name of all child accessible elements.
For example, if you have a that contains 3 "A" "B" "C", the accessibility name of the will be "A, B, C". These 3 will also be automatically excluded from accessibility focus.
This greatly facilitates accessibility, as you would need to do this manually on UWP.
A limitation of this strategy is that you can't nest interactive elements, as children of an accessible elements are excluded from accessibility focus. For example, if you put a inside another , only the parent will be focusable. This happens to match a limitation of iOS, which does this by default and forces developers to make elements as siblings instead of nesting them.
To prevent a top-level accessible element from being accessible and make its children accessibility focusable, you can set to .
Note: This is incompatible with the way accessibility works on UWP.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ComboBox.DefaultDropDownPreferredPlacement
member.summary: This defines the default value of the . (cf. Remarks.)
member.remarks: As this value is read only once when initializing the dependency property, make sure to define it in the early stages of you application initialization, before any UI related initialization (like generic styles init) and even before referencing the ** type ** ComboBox in any way.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.CompositionTarget.RenderEventThrottle
member.summary:
The delay between invocations of the event, in milliseconds. Lower values will increase the rate at which the event fires, at the expense of increased CPU usage.
This property is only used on WebAssembly.
member.remarks: The event is used by Xamarin.Forms for WebAssembly for XF animations.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ContentPresenter.UseImplicitContentFromTemplatedParent
member.summary: Enables the implicit binding Content of a ContentPresenter to the one of the TemplatedParent when this one is a ContentControl. It means you can put a `` directly in the ControlTemplate and it will be bound automatically to its TemplatedPatent's Content.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Control.UseLegacyContentAlignment
member.summary: Make the default value of VerticalContentAlignment and HorizontalContentAlignment be Stretch instead of Center

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Control.UseLegacyLazyApplyTemplate
member.summary: Enables the lazy materialization of template. This behavior is not aligned with UWP, which materializes templates immediately, making x:Name controls available in the constructor of a control.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Control.UseDeferredOnApplyTemplate
member.summary: If the call to "OnApplyTemplate" should be deferred to mimic UWP sequence of events.
member.remarks: Will never be deferred when .ApplyTemplate() is called explicitly. More information there: https://github.com/unoplatform/uno/issues/3519

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.DataTemplateSelector.UseLegacyTemplateSelectorOverload
member.summary: When set the false (default value), a call to `SelectTemplateCore(object, DependencyObject)` will be made as fallback when the `SelectTemplateCore(object)` returns null. When set to true, only `SelectTemplateCore(object)` is called (Uno's legacy mode).

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.DependencyObject.IsStoreHardReferenceEnabled
member.summary: When set to true, the will create hard references instead of weak references for some highly used fields, in common cases to improve the overall performance.
member.remarks: This feature is disabled on WebAssembly as it reveals or creates a memory corruption issue in the garbage collector. This can be revisited when upgrading tests to .NET 5+. See https://github.com/unoplatform/uno/issues/4730 for details.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Font.SymbolsFont
member.summary: Defines the default font to be used when displaying symbols, such as in SymbolIcon.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Font.IgnoreTextScaleFactor
member.summary: Ignores text scale factor, resulting in a font size as dictated by the control.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkElement.AndroidUseManagedLoadedUnloaded
member.summary: Controls the propagation of and events through managed or native visual tree traversal.
member.remarks: This setting impacts significantly the loading performance of controls on Android. Setting it to true avoids the use of costly Java->C# interop.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkElement.WasmUseManagedLoadedUnloaded
member.summary: [WebAssembly Only] Controls the propagation of and events through managed or native visual tree traversal.
member.remarks: This setting impacts significantly the loading performance of controls on WebAssembly. Setting it to true avoids the use of costly JavaScript->C# interop.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkElement.HandleLoadUnloadExceptions
member.summary: When false, skips the FrameworkElement Loading/Loaded/Unloaded exception handling. This can be disabled to improve application performance on WebAssembly. See See #7005 for additional details.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkElement.UseLegacyHitTest
member.summary: When true, any FrameworkElement with Background non-null will intercept pointer events. When set to false, the default, only certain views (Panels, Borders, and ContentPresenters) will intercept pointers if their background is non-null, while others (Control) will not, which is how WinUI behaves. Set to true if you have code written for earlier versions of Uno that relies upon the old behavior.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkTemplate.IsPoolingEnabled
member.summary: Determines if the pooling is enabled. If false, all requested instances are new.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkTemplate.TimeToLive
member.summary: Determines the duration for which a pooled template stays alive

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.FrameworkTemplate.HighMemoryThreshold
member.summary: Defines the ratio of memory usage at which the pools starts to stop pooling elligible views, between 0 and 1

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Image.LegacyIosAlignment
member.summary: Use the old way to align iOS images, using the "ContentMode". New way is using the Layer to better position the image according to alignments.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Interop.ForceJavascriptInterop
member.summary: [WebAssembly Only] Used to control the behavior of the C#/Javascript interop. Setting this flag to true forces the use of the Javascript eval mode, instead of binary interop. This flag has no effect when running in hosted mode.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Binding.IgnoreINPCSameReferences
member.summary: Determines if the binding engine should ignore identical references in binding paths.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.BindingExpression.HandleSetTargetValueExceptions
member.summary: When false, skips the BindingExpression.SetTargetValue exception handling. Can be disabled to improve application performance on WebAssembly. See See #7005 for additional details.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Popup.UseNativePopup
member.summary: Use a native popup to display the popup content. Otherwise use the .

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Popup.EnableLightDismissByDefault
member.summary: By default, light dismiss is disabled in UWP/WinUI unless is explicitly set to true. In earlier versions of Uno Platform, this property defaulted to true, which was an incorrect behavior. If your code depends on this legacy behavior, use this property to override it.

member.name: F:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ListViewBase.DefaultCacheLength
member.summary: Sets the value to use for and if not set explicitly in Xaml or code. Higher values will cache more views either side of the visible window, improving list scroll performance at the expense of consuming more memory and taking longer to initially load. Setting this to null will leave the default value at the UWP default of 4.0.

member.name: F:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.NativeListViewBase.RemoveItemAnimator
member.summary: Sets this value to remove item animation for . This prevents from crashing when pressured: Tmp detached view should be removed from RecyclerView before it can be recycled

member.name: F:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.NativeListViewBase.ForceRecycleOnDrop
member.summary: Indicates if a full recycling pass should be achieved on drop (re-order) on a ListView instead of a simple layout pass.
member.remarks: This flag should be kept to 'false' if you turned to 'false'. Forcing a recycling pass with ItemAnimator is known to cause a flicker of the whole list.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Page.IsPoolingEnabled
member.summary: Enables reuse of instances. Enabling can improve performance when using navigation.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.PointerRoutedEventArgs.AllowRelativeTimeStamp
member.summary: Defines if the PointerPoint.Timestamp retrieved from PointerRoutedEventArgs.GetCurrentPoint(relativeTo) or PointerRoutedEventArgs.GetIntermediatePoints(relativeTo) can be relative using the Android's "SystemClock.uptimeMillis()" or if they must be converted into an absolute scale (using the "elapsedRealtime()", cf. https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/SystemClock). Disabling it negatively impacts the performance it requires to compute the "sleep time" (i.e. [real elapsed time] - [up time]) for each event (as the up time is paused when device is in deep sleep). By default this is `true`.

summary.para: Determines if the visual states "PointerOver", "PointerOverSelected" are used or not. If disabled, those states will never be activated by the selector items.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Style.UseUWPDefaultStyles
member.summary:
Determines if Uno.UI should be using native styles for controls that have a native counterpart. (e.g. Button, Slider, ComboBox, ...)
By default this is true.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Style.UseUWPDefaultStylesOverride
member.summary: Override the native styles usage per control type.
member.remarks: Usage: 'UseUWPDefaultStylesOverride[typeof(Frame)] = false;' will result in the native style always being the default for Frame, irrespective of the value of . This is useful when an app uses the UWP default look for most controls but the native appearance/comportment for a few particular controls, or vice versa.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Style.ConfigureNativeFrameNavigation
member.summary: This enables native frame navigation on Android and iOS by setting related classes (, and ) to use their native styles.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Style.SetUWPDefaultStylesOverride``1(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Override the native styles useage for control type .
member.param: Whether instances of should use the UWP default style. If false, the native default style (if one exists) will be used.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.TextBlock.IsMeasureCacheEnabled
member.summary: [WebAssembly Only] Determines if the measure cache is enabled.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.TextBox.HideCaret
member.summary: Determines if the caret is visible or not.
member.remarks: This feature is used to avoid screenshot comparisons false positives

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.TextBox.UseLegacyInputScope
member.summary: The legacy prevents invalid input on hardware keyboard. This property defaults to matching UWP, where InputScope only affects the keyboard layout, but doesn't do any validation.
member.remarks: This is available on Android only

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ScrollViewer.DefaultUpdatesMode
member.summary: This defines the default value of the . For backward compatibility, you should set it to Synchronous. For better compatibility with Windows, you should keep the default value 'AsynchronousIdle'.
member.remarks: As this value is read only once when initializing the dependency property, make sure to define it in the early stages of you application initialization, before any UI related initialization (like generic styles init) and even before referencing the ** type ** ScrollViewer in any way.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ScrollViewer.DefaultAutoHideDelay
member.summary:
Defines the delay after which the scrollbars hide themselves when pointer is not over.
Default is 4 sec.
Setting this to will completely disable the auto hide feature.
member.remarks: This is effective only for managed scrollbars (WASM, macOS and Skia for now)

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ScrollViewer.AndroidScrollbarFadeDelay
member.summary: This value defines an optional delay to be set for native ScrollBar thumbs to disapear. The platform default is 300ms, which can make the thumbs appear on screenshots, changing this value to makes those disapear faster.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.ThemeAnimation.DefaultThemeAnimationDuration
member.summary: Default duration for xxxThemeAnimation

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.NativeFramePresenter.AndroidUnloadInactivePages
member.summary: Determines if pages in the backstack are kept in the visual tree. Defaults to false for performance considerations.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.UseInvalidateMeasurePath
member.summary: Call the .MeasureOverride only on element explicitly invalidating their measure and when the available size is changing.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.UseInvalidateArrangePath
member.summary: Call the .ArrangeOverride only on elements explicitly invalidating their arrange and when the final rect is changing.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.UseLegacyClipping
member.summary: [DEPRECATED] Not used anymore, does nothing.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.ShowClippingBounds
member.summary: Enable the visualization of clipping bounds (intended for diagnostic purposes).
member.remarks: This feature is only supported on iOS, for now.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.AssignDOMXamlName
member.summary: [WebAssembly Only] Enable the assignation of the "xamlname", "xuid" and "xamlautomationid" attributes on DOM elements created from the XAML visual tree. This enables tools such as Puppeteer to select elements in the DOM for automation purposes.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.RenderToStringWithId
member.summary: [WebAssembly Only] Enable UIElement.ToString() to return the element's unique ID

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.AssignDOMXamlProperties
member.summary: [WebAssembly Only] Enables the assignation of properties from the XAML visual tree as DOM attributes: Height -> "xamlheight", HorizontalAlignment -> "xamlhorizontalalignment" etc.
member.remarks:
This should only be enabled for debug builds, but can greatly aid layout debugging.
Note: for release builds of Uno, if the flag is set, attributes will be set on loading and *not* updated if the values change subsequently. This restriction doesn't apply to debug Uno builds.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.UIElement.AlwaysClipNativeChildren
member.summary: When this is set, non-UIElements will always be clipped to their bounds ( will always be set to true on their parent).
member.remarks: This is true by default as most native views assume that they will be clipped, and can display incorrectly otherwise.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.VisualState.ApplySettersBeforeTransition
member.summary: When this is set, the will be applied synchronously when changing state, unlike UWP which waits the for the end of the (if any) to apply them.
member.remarks: This flag is for backward compatibility with old versions of uno and should not be turned on.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.WebView.ForceSoftwareRendering
member.summary: Prevent the WebView from using hardware rendering. This was previously the default behavior in Uno to work around a keyboard-related visual glitch in Android 5.0 (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27172217/android-systemui-glitches-in-lollipop), however it prevents video and 3d content from being rendered.
member.remarks: See this for more info: https://github.com/unoplatform/uno/blob/26c5cc5992cae3c8c25adf51eb77ca4b0dd34e93/src/Uno.UI/UI/Xaml/Controls/WebView/WebView.Android.cs#L251_L255

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Xaml.MaxRecursiveResolvingDepth
member.summary: Maximal "BasedOn" recursive resolution depth.
member.remarks: This is a mechanism to prevent hard-to-diagnose stack overflow when a resource name is not found.

member.name: P:Uno.UI.FeatureConfiguration.Xaml.ForceHotReloadDisabled
member.summary: By default, XAML hot reload will be enabled when building in debug. Setting this flag to 'true' will force it to be disabled.

member.summary: Enumeration of the possible updates modes of a .

member.name: F:Uno.UI.Xaml.Controls.ScrollViewerUpdatesMode.Synchronous
member.summary: The ViewChanged event is raised and the VerticalOffset and HorizontalOffset are updated as soon as the native scroll presenter notifies an update.
member.remarks: This mode is required to support advance scrolling feature like parallax effect.

member.name: F:Uno.UI.Xaml.Controls.ScrollViewerUpdatesMode.AsynchronousIdle
member.summary: The raise of ViewChanged event and the VerticalOffset and HorizontalOffset updates are queued and dispatcher one idle dispatcher. Some updates may be dropped if the dispatcher is busy, but the last update will always be notified synchronously.
member.remarks: This mode is the closest to the windows behavior.

member.summary: Gets the currently active root visual - can be either public root visual or full-window media root if it is currently active.

member.summary: Replace the existing popup root (if any) with the provided one.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.VisualTree.GetPopupRootForElement(Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Static helper function that encapsulates getting the PopupRoot that is associated with the provided object. If the object is not contained within a VisualTree's tree then this method checks if the object is a Popup, or if the root of its visual tree is the logical child of a Popup. If so, it gets the PopupRoot associated with that Popup. Otherwise, this method falls back to returning the PopupRoot of the core's main VisuaTree.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.VisualTree.GetRootForElement(Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Static helper function that encapsulates walking up the tree to get the RootVisual. This function returns null if walking up the parent chain does not reach a RootVisual.
member.returns: Root visual or null.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.VisualTree.GetFocusManagerForElement(Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObject,Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.VisualTree.LookupOptions)
member.summary: Static helper function that encapsulates getting the FocusManager that is associated with the VisualTree containing the provided object. If the object is not contained within a VisualTree's tree then this method falls back to returning the FocusManager associated with the core's main VisualTree.

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.VisualTree.AddRoot(Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement)
member.summary: Adds the given root to the implicit root visual, and potentially 'Enter' it into the tree.
member.remarks: A root is entered into the tree if we can retrieve a namescope owner for it using GetNamescopeOwnerForRoot. A precondition of this function is that the root being entered is already set in its corresponding member variable (e.g. _popupRoot, _publicRootVisual, etc.)

member.name: M:Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.VisualTree.RemoveRoot(Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement)
member.summary: Removes the given root from the implicit root visual, and potentially 'Leave' it from the tree.
member.remarks: A root leaves the tree if we can retrieve a namescope owner for it using GetNamescopeOwnerForRoot. A precondition of this function is that the root being entered is already set in its corresponding member variable (e.g. m_popupRoot, m_publicRootVisual, etc.)

member.name: P:Uno.UI.BaseActivity.Current
member.summary:
Gets the currently running activity, if any.
This is the BaseActivity which is currently running, which means that it was "Resumed" and not "Paused". This may be null if the current activity does not inherit from BaseActivity, or is not yet "Created". For more info look at the lifecycle diagram documented here: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Activity.html.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.Media.Animation.DiscreteDoubleKeyFrame
member.summary: Discrete key frames like DiscreteDoubleKeyFrame create sudden "jumps" between values (no Interpolation). In other words, the animated property does not change until the key frame's key time is reached at which point the animated property goes suddenly to the target value.

member.summary: If set to , the rendering result could be better (clearer blur not mixing front elements). However due to a bug in the Xamarin framework https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/4548, debugging is impossible with this mode (causes SIGSEGV). A suggestion would be to set it to false for debug, and to true for releases.

This method is present to support adding native view types on Android, iOS and MacOS to Uno's visual tree.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.ButtonBase.OnKeyDownInternal(Windows.System.VirtualKey)
member.summary: Handles the KeyDown event for ButtonBase. Note: ENTER previously did not use ClickMode and was processed on first keydown. However keydown events are sent synchronously, so if the button was clicked using the ENTER key, the click handler could not execute code that caused reentrancy, like displaying a dialog. Such handlers are common. To solve this, ENTER was changed to use ClickMode. The default ClickMode is ClickMode.Release, and keyup events are sent asynchronously, so in the default case, click handlers can display dialogs or execute other code that causes reentrancy. If the ClickMode is changed by the app to ClickMode.Press, the click handler will not be able to execute code that causes reentrancy.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.ScrollBar.IsFixedOrientation
member.summary: Indicates if this scrollbar supports to change its orientation once its template has been applied (cf. remarks). This is false by default (which means that the ScrollBar will support dynamic orientation changes).
member.remarks: This flag is for performance consideration, it allows ScrollBar to load only half of its template. It's used by core controls (e.g. ScrollViewer) where the ScrollBar's orientation will never change. It's required as, unlike UWP, a control which is Visibility = Collapsed will get its template applied anyway.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.PlacementPopupPanel
member.summary: This is a base popup panel to calculate the placement near an anchor control.
member.remarks:
This class exists mostly to reuse the same logic between a Flyout and a ToolTip.
This class should eventually be removed, and Uno should match WinUI's approach, where Flyout sets Popup.HorizontalOffset and VerticalOffset as well as Width and Height on FlyoutPresenter when it opens, and then allows the popup layouting to do its job.
See also remarks on .

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ContentControl.IsContentPresenterBypassEnabled
member.summary: This property determines if the current instance is not providing a Control Template, to allow for the ContentControl to avoid using a ContentPresenter. This extra layer is a problem on Android, where the stack size is severely limited (32KB at most) on version 4.4 and earlier. Android 5.0 does not have this limitation, because ART requires greater stack sizes.
member.remarks: If the default style for the current type has a Template property, we know that the IsContentPresenterBypassEnabled will be false once the style has been set. Return false in this case, even if the Template is null.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Control.GetTemplateChild``1(System.String)
member.summary: Finds a realized element in the control template of the specified type.
member.typeparam: The type of the template part.
member.param: The name of the template part.
member.returns: The first template part of the specified name; otherwise, null.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Control.CanCreateTemplateWithoutParent
member.summary: Allows to bypass the validation of the presence of a parent.
member.remarks:
Setting to true property allows the ContentControl to create its children even if no parent view has been set. This is used for the ListView control (and other virtualizing controls) to measure items properly. These controls set the size of the view based on the size reported immediately after the BaseAdapter.GetView method returns, but the parent still has not been set.
The Content control uses this delayed creation as an optimization technique for layout creation, when controls are created but not yet used.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Control.SetDefaultStyleKey``1(``0)
member.summary: Duplicates the SetDefaultStyleKey() helper method from WinUI code.
member.remarks: Note: Although this is usually called as 'SetDefaultStyleKey(this)' (per WinUI C++ code), we actually only use the compile-time TDerived type and ignore the runtime derivedControl parameter, preserving the expected behaviour that DefaultStyleKey is 'fixed' under inheritance unless explicitly changed by an inheriting type.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Image.PreserveStateOnUnload
member.summary: Setting this flag instructs the image control not to dispose pending image fetches when it is removed from the visual tree. This should generally be left false, but may be required in cases that the image is rapidly unloaded and reloaded, or that OnUnloaded/OnDetachedFromWindow is improperly called when the view isn't really being removed, and performance/stability is affected.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether we should allow to downgrade a request for remeasure and layout to redraw the image only. This value can be set to false as a workaround to issues caused by optimizations introduced with ShouldDowngradeLayoutRequest. Default value: true

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Image.ShouldDowngradeLayoutRequest
member.summary: Check whether we should downgrade a request for remeasure and layout to a request to redraw the image only, ie because we know that the image's dimensions have not changed after setting the source.
member.returns: True if we know that the image's dimensions have not changed.

indicates that the size of the image source is in logical pixels (this is the case when the source is an URI)

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Image.MustDispatchSetSource
member.summary: If the image control does not have finite bounds, or if finite bounds have not yet been computed, then it must go through another measure/arrange pass after the image is set. This is not guaranteed to happen if RequestLayout is called from within a layout pass, so we must set the image on the dispatcher even if we wouldn't otherwise.

member.summary:
Gets a flattened item index. Unlike , this can not be overridden to adjust for supplementary elements (eg headers) on derived controls. This represents the (flattened) index in the data source as opposed to the 'display' index.
Note that the is still the 'display' value in that it doesn't 'know about' empty groups if HidesIfEmpty is set to true.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ItemsControl.TryRepairContentConnection(Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ContentControl,System.Object)
member.summary: Ensure the container template updates correctly when recycling with the same item.
member.remarks:
This addresses the very specific case where 1) the item is a view, 2) It's being rebound to a container that was most recently used to show that same view, but 3) the view is no longer connected to the container, perhaps because it was bound to a different container in the interim.
To force the item view to be reconnected, we set DataContext to null, so that when we set it to the item view immediately afterward, it does something instead of nothing.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ItemsControl.IsItemItsOwnContainerOverride(System.Object)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified item is (or is eligible to be) its own container.
member.returns: true if the item is (or is eligible to be) its own container; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ItemsControl.GetContainerForIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a new container for item at and returns it, unless the item is its own container, in which case returns the item itself, or the template root is a suitable container, in which case the template root is returned.
member.remarks: For virtualized controls, this method is only called if it's not possible to recycle an existing container.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.ItemsControl.GetContainerForTemplate(Windows.UI.Xaml.DataTemplate)
member.summary: Gets an appropriate container for a given template (either a new container, or the template's root if it is a container)
member.remarks: This is called directly by NativeListViewBase on Android rather than , since the recycling mechanism doesn't permit for the exact item index to be known when the container is created.

true to disable zoom/pan animations while changing the view; otherwise, false. The default is false.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Slider.IsTrackerEnabled
member.summary:
Enables or disables tracking on the Slider container.
When enabled, the Slider will intercept touch events on the entire container as well as the Thumb. This is the default value.
When disabled, only the Thumb will intercept touch events. Therefore, the user cannot tap or drag on the bar to change the Slider's value. This is a better option in cases involving Sliders within a ScrollView, to avoid the Slider stealing the focus when the user tries to scroll.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.TextBox.ShouldForceDisableSpellCheck
member.summary: If true, and is false, take vigorous measures to ensure that spell-check (ie predictive text) is really disabled.
member.remarks: Specifically, when true, and is false, this sets on the inner . This is required because a number of OEM keyboards (particularly on older devices?) ignore the . It's optional because setting the password InputType is a workaround which is known to cause issues in certain circumstances. See discussion here: https://stackoverflow.com/a/5188119/1902058

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.TextBox.PreventKeyboardDisplayIfSet
member.summary: Applies PreventKeyboardDisplayOnProgrammaticFocus by temporarily disabling soft input display.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.TextBox.TextBoxStringBuilder
member.summary: Subclass of which allows input text to be modified by 's event handlers.
member.remarks: Overriding the method is more powerful than applying an to the native text field, because we can make arbitrary modifications to the entire content string, whereas only allows modifications to the new text being added to the buffer.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.TextBox.TextBoxInputConnection
member.summary: Intercepts communication between the software keyboard and , in order to prevent incorrect changes.
member.remarks:
Certain keyboards get confused when the input string is changed by TextChanging, particularly in the case of predictive text. We override the method to intercept erroneous changes.
Most overrides are delegated to the EditableInputConnection object returned by the base EditText.OnCreateInputConnection() method (which can't be directly subclassed because it's internal).

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.VirtualizingPanelLayout.GetNextUnmaterializedItem(Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.GeneratorDirection,System.Nullable{Uno.UI.IndexPath})
member.summary: Get the index of the next item that has not yet been materialized in the nominated fill direction. Returns null if there are no more available items in the source.

members.member:
Notes: For the sake of minimizing conditional branches, almost all the layouting logic is carried out relative to the scroll direction. To avoid confusion, a number of terms are used in place of terms like 'width' and 'height':
Extent: Size along the dimension parallel to scrolling. The equivalent of 'Height' if scrolling is vertical, or 'Width' otherwise. Breadth: Size along the dimension orthogonal to scrolling. The equivalent of 'Width' if scrolling is vertical, or 'Height' otherwise. Start: The edge of the element nearest to the top of the content panel, ie 'Top' or 'Left' depending whether scrolling is vertical or horizontal. End: The edge of the element nearest to the bottom of the content panel, ie 'Bottom' or 'Right' depending whether scrolling is vertical or horizontal.
Leading: When scrolling, the edge that is coming into view. ie, if the scrolling forward in a vertical orientation, the bottom edge. Trailing: When scrolling, the edge that is disappearing from view.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.VirtualizingPanelLayout.IsReorderingAndNotReadyToScroll(Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.GeneratorDirection)
member.summary: During a drag-to-reorder, if the item is dragged very rapidly then we may receive a scroll request before the item has been redrawn at the position under the cursor. If the item is still at the beginning of the list (that is, the 'trailing' position relative to scroll), this would violate the assumptions of the reordering logic (). As a simple fix we simply skip this scroll request, and wait for one to occur after the item has been repositioned.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.VirtualizingPanelLayout.ScrollByInner(System.Int32,AndroidX.RecyclerView.Widget.RecyclerView.Recycler,AndroidX.RecyclerView.Widget.RecyclerView.State)
member.summary: Materialize and dematerialize views corresponding to their visibility after the requested scroll offset.
member.remarks: In essence: fill the window that is attempting to make visible, and unfill views outside of that window.
member.returns: The actual scroll offset (which may be less than requested if the end of the list is reached).

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.InitialsGenerator.InitialsFromContactObject(Windows.ApplicationModel.Contacts.Contact)
member.summary: Helper function which takes in a Contact object and produces initials which represent that contact.
member.remarks: INTENDED LOGIC BEHAVIOR: - If the name contains glyphs, return a generic icon. - If we have access to First Name vs. Last Name data (First Name being set regionally - i.e. it equals Given Name or Family Name based on system setting), . If non-symbolic, use the first letter of the First Name and first letter of the Last Name . If symbolic, use the first character of the Given Name - If we don't have access to First/Last or Given/Family Name, (i.e. long string Dr. Jordan von Hammerspike III) . If non-symbolic, break by space delimiter then follow the following rules: -. Use the first letter of the first word and the first letter of the last word -. If only one word, use a single letter . If symbolic, use the first one or two characters of the string (decided by how squished it looks visually) -. Note: This branch of the logic falls apart in the Family Name, Given Name case.

member.summary: The pane covers the content when it's open and does not take up space in the control layout. The pane closes when the user taps outside of it.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.SplitViewDisplayMode.Inline
member.summary: The pane is shown side-by-side with the content and takes up space in the control layout. The pane does not close when the user taps outside of it.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.SplitViewDisplayMode.CompactOverlay
member.summary: The amount of the pane defined by the CompactPaneLength property is shown side-by-side with the content and takes up space in the control layout. The remaining part of the pane covers the content when it's open and does not take up space in the control layout. The pane closes when the user taps outside of it.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.SplitViewDisplayMode.CompactInline
member.summary: The amount of the pane defined by the CompactPaneLength property is shown side-by-side with the content and takes up space in the control layout. The remaining part of the pane pushes the content to the side when it's open and takes up space in the control layout. The pane does not close when the user taps outside of it.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.OrientedSize
member.summary: The OrientedSize structure is used to abstract the growth direction from the layout algorithms of WrapPanel. When the growth direction is oriented horizontally (ex: the next element is arranged on the side of the previous element), then the Width grows directly with the placement of elements and Height grows indirectly with the size of the largest element in the row. When the orientation is reversed, so is the directional growth with respect to Width and Height.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason
member.summary: Defines values that represent the reasons that the Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement got focus in a desktop application that uses a DesktopWindowXamlSource object to host XAML-based UI. The XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.Reason property returns one of these values.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Programmatic
member.summary: The focus was set programmatically.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Restore
member.summary: The focus was restored after a task switch, such as pressing Alt + Tab.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.First
member.summary: The focus was set in response to the user navigating to the next element by using a bidirectional navigation experience (for example, by pressing Tab).

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Last
member.summary: The focus was set in response to the user navigating to the previous element by using a bidirectional navigation experience (for example, by pressing Shift-Tab).

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Left
member.summary: The focus was set in response to the user navigating left by using a 4-direction navigation experience (for example, by using keyboard arrow keys).

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Up
member.summary: The focus was set in response to the user navigating up by using a 4-direction navigation experience (for example, by using keyboard arrow keys).

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Right
member.summary: The focus was set in response to the user navigating right by using a 4-direction navigation experience (for example, by using keyboard arrow keys).

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason.Down
member.summary: The focus was set in response to the user navigating down by using a 4-direction navigation experience (for example, by using keyboard arrow keys).

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.#ctor(Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest class with the reason for the navigation request.
member.param: A value that indicates the reason for the navigation request.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.#ctor(Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason,Windows.Foundation.Rect)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest class with the reason for the navigation request and the bounding rectangle that will receive navigation focus.
member.param: A value that indicates the reason for the navigation request.
The bounding rectangle of the element in the desktop application that is losing focus.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.#ctor(Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationReason,Windows.Foundation.Rect,System.Guid)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest class with the reason for the navigation request, the bounding rectangle that will receive navigation focus, and the unique correlation ID for the request.
member.param: A value that indicates the reason for the navigation request.
The bounding rectangle of the element in the desktop application that is losing focus.

The unique identifier for the navigation request. You can use this parameter for logging purposes, or if you have an existing correlation ID from an in-progress focus movement already in progress and you want to connect that focus movement with the current navigation request.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.Reason
member.summary: Gets the unique identifier for the navigation request. You can use this value for logging purposes, or if you have an existing correlation ID from an in-progress focus movement already in progress and you want to connect that focus movement with a new navigation request.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.HintRect
member.summary: Gets the bounding rectangle of the element in the desktop application that is losing focus (that is, the element that had focus before the DesktopWindowXamlSource received focus).

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Hosting.XamlSourceFocusNavigationRequest.CorrelationId
member.summary: Gets the unique identifier for the navigation request. You can use this value for logging purposes, or if you have an existing correlation ID from an in-progress focus movement already in progress and you want to connect that focus movement with a new navigation request.

member.name: E:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.GotFocus
member.summary: Occurs when an element within a container element (a focus scope) receives focus. This event is raised asynchronously, so focus might move before bubbling is complete.

member.name: E:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.LostFocus
member.summary: Occurs when an element within a container element (a focus scope) loses focus. This event is raised asynchronously, so focus might move again before bubbling is complete.

member.name: E:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.GettingFocus
member.summary: Occurs before an element actually receives focus. This event is raised synchronously to ensure focus isn't moved while the event is bubbling.

member.name: E:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.LosingFocus
member.summary: Occurs before focus moves from the current element with focus to the target element. This event is raised synchronously to ensure focus isn't moved while the event is bubbling.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.TryFocusAsync(Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObject,Windows.UI.Xaml.FocusState)
member.summary: Asynchronously attempts to set focus on an element when the application is initialized.
member.param: The object on which to set focus.
One of the values from the FocusState enumeration that specify how an element can obtain focus.
member.returns: The that indicates whether focus was successfully set.
member.remarks: Completes synchronously when called on an element running in the app process.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.TryMoveFocus(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusNavigationDirection)
member.summary: Attempts to change focus from the element with focus to the next focusable element in the specified direction.
member.returns: true if focus moved; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: The tab order is the order in which a user moves from one control to another by pressing the Tab key (forward) or Shift+Tab (backward). This method uses tab order sequence and behavior to traverse all focusable elements in the UI. If the focus is on the first element in the tab order and FocusNavigationDirection.Previous is specified, focus moves to the last element. If the focus is on the last element in the tab order and FocusNavigationDirection.Next is specified, focus moves to the first element. Other directions are not supported on all platforms.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.TryMoveFocus(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusNavigationDirection,Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FindNextElementOptions)
member.summary: Attempts to change focus from the element with focus to the next focusable element in the specified direction, using the specified navigation options.
member.param: The direction to traverse (in tab order).
The options to help identify the next element to receive focus with keyboard/controller/remote navigation.
member.returns: true if focus moved; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: The tab order is the order in which a user moves from one control to another by pressing the Tab key (forward) or Shift+Tab (backward). This method uses tab order sequence and behavior to traverse all focusable elements in the UI. If the focus is on the first element in the tab order and FocusNavigationDirection.Previous is specified, focus moves to the last element. If the focus is on the last element in the tab order and FocusNavigationDirection.Next is specified, focus moves to the first element. Other directions are not supported on all platforms.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.TryMoveFocusAsync(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusNavigationDirection)
member.summary: Asynchronously attempts to change focus from the current element with focus to the next focusable element in the specified direction.
member.param: The direction that focus moves from element to element within the app UI.
member.returns: The that indicates whether focus was successfully set.

member.param: The direction that focus moves from element to element within the app UI.
The navigation options used to identify the focus candidate.
member.returns: The that indicates whether focus was successfully set.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager._canTabOutOfPlugin
member.summary: This is a leftover from Silverlight times :-) . When the platform cannot support tabbing out of plugin, we will act as if there is an implicit top-level TabNavigation="Cycle" So instead of tabbing out, we handle the "last" tab by cycling to the "first" tab. This is deemed better than getting stuck at the end. (Reverse "first" and "last" for Shift-Tab.)

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager._engagedControl
member.summary: Represents the control which is focus-engaged.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager._focusLocked
member.summary: Represents a value indicating whether focus is currently locked.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager._ignoreFocusLock
member.summary: During Window Activation/Deactivation, we lock focus. However, focus can move internally via the focused element becoming unfocusable (ie. leaving the tree or changing visibility). This member will force focus manager to bypass the _focusLocked logic. This should be used with care... if used irresponsibly, we can enable unsupported reentrancy scenarios.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager._currentFocusOperationCancellable
member.summary: It is possible to continue with a focus operation, even though focus is locked. In this case, we need to ensure that we persist the fact that focus should not be canceled.

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager._asyncOperation
member.summary: This represents the async operation that can initiated through a public async FocusManager method, such as TryFocusAsync. We store it as a memeber because the operation can continue to run even after the api has finished executing.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.UpdateFocus(Uno.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusMovement)
member.summary:
Changes our currently focused element. FocusMovementResult.WasMoved indicates whether the update is successful. We will also be responsible for raising focus related events (GettingFocus/LosingFocus and GotFocus/LostFocus).
FocusMovementResult.WasMoved indicates that the process has executed successfully.
member.remarks:
We have two ways (FocusMovementResult.GetHResult() and FocusMovementResult.WasMoved) to report success and failure. This is because it is possible that the given pNewFocus could not actually take focus for innocent reasons. (Currently in disabled state, etc.) This is not an important failure and GetHResult() return S_OK even though WasMoved() is false.
A failing HRESULT is reserved for important failures like OOM conditions or reentrancy prevention. This distinction is made in the interest of reducing noise in tools like XcpMon.
Boundary cases: - If pNewFocus is the object that already has current focus, it is counted as success even though nothing was technically "updated".
- If a focus change is cancelled in a Getting/Losing Focus handler, it is counted as success even though focus was technically not "updated".

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManager.GetAppVisibleXamlRootContent(Uno.UI.Xaml.Core.ContentRoot)
member.summary: Gets the XamlRoot.Content object as seen by the app, so we can use it to compare against a parameter. This is because some of our APIs (FocusManager TryNextFocus/FindNextElement) specifically allow an app to scope a search to the XamlRoot level (by passing in XamlRoot.Content) but not for arbitrary elements. This function calls XamlRoot.Content the way the app would.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.FocusManagerGotFocusEventArgs.CorrelationId
member.summary: Gets the unique ID generated when a focus movement event is initiated.
member.remarks: Each time a focus event is initiated, a unique CorrelationId is generated to help you track a focus event throughout these focus actions. A new CorrelationId is generated when: - The user moves focus. - The app moves focus using methods such as Control.Focus or FocusManager.TryFocusAsync. - The app gets/loses focus due to window activation(see CoreWindow.Activated ).

member.summary: Indicates that focus moves to the first element encountered when projecting the edge of the currently focused element in the direction of navigation.

member.summary: Indicates that focus moves to the closest element based on the shortest 2D distance (Manhattan metric).

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.BringIntoViewOptions.HorizontalAlignmentRatio
member.summary: Controls the positioning of the vertical axis of the TargetRect with respect to the vertical axis of the viewport. The value is clamped from 0.0f to 1.0f with 0.0f representing the left vertical edge and 1.0f representing the right vertical edge. By default this is set to 0.0f.

member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal distance to add to the viewport-relative position of the TargetRect after satisfying the requested HorizontalAlignmentRatio.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.BringIntoViewOptions.TargetRect
member.summary: Gets or sets the area of an element to bring into view.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.BringIntoViewOptions.VerticalAlignmentRatio
member.summary: Controls the positioning of the horizontal axis of the TargetRect with respect to the horizontal axis of the viewport. The value is clamped from 0.0f to 1.0f with 0.0f representing the top horizontal edge and 1.0f representing the bottom horizontal edge. By default this is set to 0.0f.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.BringIntoViewOptions.VerticalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical distance to add to the viewport-relative position of the TargetRect after satisfying the requested VerticalAlignmentRatio.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyProperty.ForceInitializeTypeConstructor(System.Type)
member.summary: Forces the invocation of the cctor of a type and its base types that may contain DependencyProperty registrations.
member.remarks:
This is required because of the lazy initialization nature of the classes that do not contain an explicit type ctor, but contain statically initialized fields. DependencyProperty.Register may not be called as a result, if none of the DependencyProperty fields are accessed prior to the enumeration of the fields via reflection.
This method avoids requiring controls to include an explicit type constructor to function properly.
See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6729841/why-did-the-beforefieldinit-behavior-change-in-net-4

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.RoutedEvent.IsAlwaysBubbled
member.summary: Determines if this event is bubbled to the parent, not matter is a parent is subscribed to the handler with the flag handledEventToo or not.
member.remarks:
For some events like PointerEvent, we always needs to get the full events sequence to maintain the internal state, so we always needs the handled events too.
This flag avoids the complex update of the SubscribedToHandledEventsToo property coercing and inheritance for those kind of well-known events.
Basically all routed events that are implementing the 'PrepareManaged***EventBubbling' to maintain local state should opt-in for that.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.RoutedEventArgs.CanBubbleNatively
member.summary: If this event is currently coming from platform (native) and CAN bubble natively.
member.remarks: See Uno documentation to understand the difference between _native_ and _managed_ bubbling.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.PointerCaptureTarget.Element
member.summary: The target element to which event args should be forwarded

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.PointerCaptureTarget.NativeCaptureElement
member.summary: The element to used for the native capture
member.remarks: On WASM this might be different than the : In case of implicit capture, the element used for the capture will prevent any pointer event on sub element (sub element will actually get a pointer 'leave' on capture, and a 'enter' on capture release). So instead of capturing using the actual element, we use the 'OriginalSource' of the 'relatedArgs', so event will still be sent to sub elements and we will then filter them out if needed.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.PointerCaptureTarget.Kind
member.summary: Gets tha current capture kind that was enabled on the target

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.PointerCaptureTarget.IsInNativeBubblingTree
member.summary:
Determines if the is in the native bubbling tree. If so we could rely on standard events bubbling to reach it. Otherwise this means that we have to bubble the event in managed only.
This makes sense only for platform that has "implicit capture" (i.e. all pointers events are sent to the element on which the pointer pressed occured at the beginning of the gesture). This is the case on iOS and Android.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.PointerCaptureTarget.LastDispatched
member.summary: Gets the last event dispatched by the . In case of native bubbling (cf. ), this helps to determine that an event was already dispatched by the Owner: if a UIElement is receiving and event with the same timestamp, it means that the element is a parent of the Owner and we are only bubbling the routed event, so this element can raise the event (if the opposite, it means that the element is a child, so it has to mute the event).

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.ArePointersEnabled
member.summary: Validates that this element is able to manage pointer events. If this element is only the shadow of a ghost native view that was instantiated for marshalling purposes by Xamarin, the _gestures instance will be invalid and trying to interpret a native pointer event might crash the app. This flag should be checked when receiving a pointer related event from the native view to prevent this case.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.GetHitTestVisibility
member.summary: Indicates if this element or one of its child might be target pointer pointer events. Be aware this doesn't means that the element itself can be actually touched by user, but only that pointer events can be raised on this element. I.e. this element is NOT .

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.CompleteGesture
member.summary: Prevents the gesture recognizer to generate a manipulation. It's designed to be invoked in Pointers events handlers.

member.summary: Provides ability to a control to fulfill the data that is going to be shared, by drag-and-drop for instance.
member.remarks: This is expected to be overriden by controls like Image or TextBlock to self fulfill data.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.OnNativePointerCancel(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.PointerRoutedEventArgs,System.Boolean)
member.summary: When the system cancel a pointer pressed, either 1. because the pointing device was lost/disconnected, 2. or the system detected something meaning full and will handle this pointer internally. This second case is the more common (e.g. ScrollViewer) and should be indicated using the flag.
member.param: Indicates that the pointer was muted by the system which will handle it internally.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.IsPointerOver
member.summary: Indicates if a pointer (no matter the pointer) is currently over the element (i.e. OverState) WARNING: This might not be maintained for all controls, cf. remarks.
member.remarks: This flag is updated by the managed Pointers events handling, however on Android and WebAssembly, pointer events are marshaled to the managed code only if there is some listeners to the events. So it means that this flag will be maintained only if you subscribe at least to one pointer event (or override one of the OnPointer*** methods).

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.IsOver(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.Pointer)
member.summary: Indicates if a pointer is currently over the element (i.e. OverState) WARNING: This might not be maintained for all controls, cf. remarks.
member.remarks: The over state is updated by the managed Pointers events handling, however on Android and WebAssembly, pointer events are marshaled to the managed code only if there is some listeners to the events. So it means that this method will give valid state only if you subscribe at least to one pointer event (or override one of the OnPointer*** methods).

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.IsPointerPressed
member.summary: Indicates if a pointer was pressed while over the element (i.e. PressedState). Note: The pressed state will remain true even if the pointer exits the control (while pressed) WARNING: This might not be maintained for all controls, cf. remarks.
member.remarks: This flag is updated by the managed Pointers events handling, however on Android and WebAssembly, pointer events are marshaled to the managed code only if there is some listeners to the events. So it means that this flag will be maintained only if you subscribe at least to one pointer event (or override one of the OnPointer*** methods).

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.IsPressed(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.Pointer)
member.summary: Indicates if a pointer was pressed while over the element (i.e. PressedState) Note: The pressed state will remain true even if the pointer exits the control (while pressed) WARNING: This might not be maintained for all controls, cf. remarks.
member.remarks: The pressed state is updated by the managed Pointers events handling, however on Android and WebAssembly, pointer events are marshaled to the managed code only if there is some listeners to the events. So it means that this method will give valid state only if you subscribe at least to one pointer event (or override one of the OnPointer*** methods).

Note that on UWP the "pressed" state is managed **PER POINTER**, and not per pressed button on the given pointer. It means that with a mouse if you follow this sequence : press left => press right => release right => release left, you will get only one 'PointerPressed' and one 'PointerReleased'. Same thing if you release left first (press left => press right => release left => release right), and for the pen's barrel button.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.HasPointerCapture
member.summary: Indicates if this UIElement has any active ** EXPLICIT ** pointer capture.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.ReleasePointerCapture(Windows.Devices.Input.PointerIdentifier,System.Boolean,Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.PointerCaptureKind)
member.summary: Release a pointer capture with the ability to not raise the event (cf. Remarks)
member.remarks: On some controls we use the Capture to track the pressed state properly, to detect click. But in few cases (i.e. Hyperlink) UWP does not raise a PointerCaptureLost. This method give the ability to easily follow this behavior without requiring the control to track and handle the event.
member.param: Determines if the event should be raised or not.
The kind of captures to release.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.IsDragOver(Windows.UI.Xaml.Input.Pointer)
member.summary: Gets a boolean which indicates if there is currently a Drag and Drop operation pending over this element. This indicates that a **data package is currently being dragged over this element and might be dropped** on this element or one of its children, and not that this element nor one of its children element is being drag. As this flag reflect the state of the element **or one of its children**, it might be True event if `DropAllowed` is `false`.
member.param: The pointer associated to the drag and drop operation

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingContext.OnManagedBubbling
member.summary: When bubbling in managed code, the will take care to raise the event on each parent, considering the Handled flag. This value is used to flag events that are sent to element to maintain their internal state, but which are not meant to initiate a new event bubbling (a.k.a. invoke the "RaiseEvent" again)

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingContext.Mode
member.summary: The mode to use for bubbling

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingContext.Root
member.summary: An optional root element on which the bubbling should stop.
member.remarks: It's expected that the event is raised on this Root element.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingContext.IsInternal
member.summary: Indicates that the associated event should not be publicly raised.
member.remarks: The "internal" here refers only to the private state of the code which has initiated this event, not subclasses. This means that an event flagged as "internal" can bubble to update the private state of parents, but the UIElement.RoutedEvent won't be raised in any way (public and internal handlers) and it won't be sent to Control.On`RoutedEvent`() neither.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingMode
member.summary: Defines the mode used to bubble an event.
member.remarks: This takes priority over the . Preventing default bubble behavior of an event is meant to be used only when the event has already been raised/bubbled, but we need to sent it also to some specific elements (e.g. implicit captures).

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingMode.Bubble
member.summary: The event should bubble normally in this element and its parent

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingMode.IgnoreElement
member.summary: The event should not be raised on current element

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingMode.IgnoreParents
member.summary: The event should not bubble to parent elements

member.name: F:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.BubblingMode.NoBubbling

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.TransientArrangeFinalRect

member.name: P:Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement.FrameRoundingAdjustment
member.summary:
The difference between the physical layout width and height taking the origin into account, and the physical width and height that would've been calculated for an origin of (0,0). The difference may be -1,0, or +1 pixels due to different roundings.
(Eg, consider a Grid that is 31 logical pixels high, with 3 children with alignment Stretch in successive Star-sized rows. Each child will be measured with a logical height of 10.3, and logical origins of 0, 10.3, and 20.6. Assume the device scale is 1. The child origins will be converted to 0, 10, and 21 respectively in integer pixel values; this will give heights of 10, 11, and 10 pixels. The FrameRoundingAdjustment values will be (0,0), (0,1), and (0,0) respectively.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObjectStore.CreateWeakDelegate(Windows.UI.Xaml.PropertyChangedCallback,Windows.UI.Xaml.PropertyChangedCallback@,Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObjectStore.WeakReferenceReturnDisposable@)
member.summary: Creates a weak delegate for the specified PropertyChangedCallback callback.
member.remarks:
This method is used to avoid creating a hard link between the source instance and the stored delegate for the instance, thus avoid memory leaks. We also do not need to clear the delegate created because it is already associated with the instance.
Note that this method is not generic to avoid the cost of trampoline resolution on Mono 4.2 and earlier, when Full AOT is enabled. This should be revised once this behavior is updated, or the cost of calling generic delegates is lowered.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObjectStore.CreateWeakDelegate(Windows.UI.Xaml.ExplicitPropertyChangedCallback,Windows.UI.Xaml.ExplicitPropertyChangedCallback@,Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyObjectStore.WeakReferenceReturnDisposable@)
member.summary: Creates a weak delegate for the specified ExplicitPropertyChangedCallback callback.
member.remarks:
This method is used to avoid creating a hard link between the source instance and the stored delegate for the instance, thus avoid memory leaks. We also do not need to clear the delegate created because it is already associated with the instance.
Note that this method is not generic to avoid the cost of trampoline resolution on Mono 4.2 and earlier, when Full AOT is enabled. This should be revised once this behavior is updated, or the cost of calling generic delegates is lowered.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.DependencyPropertyDetailsCollection
member.summary: A collection
A collection
member.remarks:
This implementation uses an O(1) lookup for the dependency properties of a DependencyObject. This assumes that returns an ordered list, and creates an array based on the min and max UniqueIDs found in the object's properties.
This approach can cost more in storage for some types, if the array is mostly empty.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Xaml.DispatcherConditionalDisposable
member.summary: A class that executes the dispose action on the Dispatcher.
member.remarks:
This class is generally used to ensure that a delegate instance can be tied to its target property instance, while being a weak reference.
This enables scenarios such as passing a capturing lambda to be passed as a callback, and not have to unintended memory leaks on either the sender or receiver of the callback.

member.summary: Provides an instance pool for FrameworkTemplates, when is called.
member.remarks:
The pooling is particularly important on iOS and Android where the memory management is less than ideal because of the pinning of native instances, and the inability of the GC to determine that two instances refer to each other via a native storage (Subviews for instance), and reclaim their memory properly.
The pooling is also important because creating a control is particularly expensive on Android and iOS.
This Xaml implementation relies on unloaded controls to release their templated parent by setting it to null, which always resets content template of a ContentControl, as well as the template of a Control. This forces recycled controls to re-create their templates even if it was previously the same. This can make lists particularly jittery. This class allows for templates to be reused, based on the fact that controls created via a FrameworkTemplate that lose their DependencyObject.Parent value are considered orhpans. Those instances can then later on be reused.
This behavior is not following windows' implementation, as this requires a control to be stateless. This is pretty easy to do when controls are strictly databound, but not if the control is using stateful code-behind. This is why this behavior can be disabled via if the pooling interferes with the normal behavior of a control.

member.summary: Determines the duration for which a pooled template stays alive.

member.summary: Determines if the pooling is enabled. If false, all requested instances are new.

member.summary: Defines the ratio of memory usage at which the pools starts to stop pooling elligible views.

member.summary: Registers a custom

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.FrameworkTemplatePool.Scavenge
member.summary: Release all templates that are currently held by the pool.
member.remarks: The pool will periodically release templates that haven't been reused within the span of , so normally you shouldn't need to call this method. It may be useful in advanced memory management scenarios.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Xaml.FrameworkTemplatePool.ReleaseTemplateRoot(Android.Views.View,Windows.UI.Xaml.FrameworkTemplate)
member.summary: Manually return an unused template root to the pool.
member.remarks: We disable cleaning the elements inside the template root because it may cause problems. It's safe to assume the template root is still 'clean' because it was never made available to application code.

member.name: T:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.InfoBar
member.summary: An InfoBar is an inline notification for essential app-wide messages. The InfoBar will take up space in a layout and will not cover up other content or float on top of it. It supports rich content (including titles, messages, icons, and buttons) and can be configured to be user-dismissable or persistent.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the Closing event should be canceled in the InfoBar.

member.name: T:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.InfoBarSeverity
member.summary: Defines constants that indicate the criticality of the InfoBar that is shown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.InfoBarSeverity.Informational
member.summary: Communicates that the InfoBar is displaying general information that requires the user's attention. For assistive technologies, they will follow the behavior set in the Processing_All constant.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.InfoBarSeverity.Success
member.summary: Communicates that the InfoBar is displaying information regarding a long-running and/or background task that has completed successfully. For assistive technologies, they will follow the behavior set in the Processing_All constant.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.InfoBarSeverity.Warning
member.summary: Communicates that the InfoBar is displaying information regarding a condition that might cause a problem in the future. For assistive technologies, they will follow the behavior set in the NotificationProcessing_ImportantAll constant.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.InfoBarSeverity.Error
member.summary: Communicates that the InfoBar is displaying information regarding an error or problem that has occurred. For assistive technologies, they will follow the behavior set in the NotificationProcessing_ImportantAll constant.

member.summary: The pane is shown at the top of the control.

member.summary: The pane is shown on the left side of the control. Only the pane icons are shown by default.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.NavigationViewPaneDisplayMode.LeftMinimal
member.summary: The pane is shown on the left side of the control. Only the pane menu button is shown by default.

member.name: M:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.VirtualizingLayout.IsSignificantViewportChange(Windows.Foundation.Rect,Windows.Foundation.Rect)
member.summary: Determines if the difference between 2 viewports is large enough to cause a layout pass. ** This is Uno specific ** This has been introduced to reduce the number of layouting pass for performance considerations. However a too high threshold would cause longer passes (as more items would been added / removed at once). Note: this is used only for viewport, if the size of the ItemsRepeater changes it will still be re-layouted.

member.summary: Defines constants that describe the behavior of the close button contained within each TabViewItem.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TabViewCloseButtonOverlayMode.Auto
member.summary: Behavior is defined by the framework. Default. This value maps to Always.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TabViewCloseButtonOverlayMode.OnPointerOver
member.summary: The selected tab always shows the close button if it is closable. Unselected tabs show the close button when the tab is closable and the user has their pointer over the tab.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TabViewCloseButtonOverlayMode.Always
member.summary: The selected tab always shows the close button if it is closable. Unselected tabs always show the close button if they are closable.

member.name: T:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewMode
member.summary: Defines constants that specify how panes are shown in a TwoPaneView.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewMode.SinglePane
member.summary: Only one pane is shown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewMode.Wide
member.summary: Panes are shown side-by-side.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewMode.Tall
member.summary: Panes are shown top-bottom.

member.name: T:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewPriority
member.summary: Defines constants that specify which pane has priority in a TwoPaneView.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewPriority.Pane1
member.summary: Pane 1 has priority.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewPriority.Pane2
member.summary: Pane 2 has priority.

member.name: T:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewTallModeConfiguration
member.summary: Defines constants that specify how panes are shown in a TwoPaneView in tall mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewTallModeConfiguration.SinglePane
member.summary: Only the pane that has priority is shown, the other pane is hidden.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewTallModeConfiguration.TopBottom
member.summary: The pane that has priority is shown on top, the other pane is shown on the bottom.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewTallModeConfiguration.BottomTop
member.summary: The pane that has priority is shown on the bottom, the other pane is shown on top.

member.name: T:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewWideModeConfiguration
member.summary: Defines constants that specify how panes are shown in a TwoPaneView in wide mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewWideModeConfiguration.SinglePane
member.summary: Only the pane that has priority is shown, the other pane is hidden.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewWideModeConfiguration.LeftRight
member.summary: The pane that has priority is shown on the left, the other pane is shown on the right.

member.name: F:Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Controls.TwoPaneViewWideModeConfiguration.RightLeft
member.summary: The pane that has priority is shown on the right, the other pane is shown on the left.
